dataset.title: Bathymetry and watershed area for Falling Creek Reservoir, Beaverdam Reservoir, and Carvins Cove Reservoir

abstract.para: This data package includes bathymetric data and watershed delineations for Falling Creek (FCR), Beaverdam (BVR), and Carvins Cove (CCR) Reservoirs, all located near Roanoke, VA, USA. Bathymetric data were collected using an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) and processed using WinRiver II and ArcGIS. Water level can vary in these reservoirs; at the time of ADCP measurement, maximum depth was ~9.3 m in FCR, ~13.5 m in BVR, and ~23 m in CCR. Bathymetric data are presented in two forms: (1) as hypsometric summaries of surface area and volume for 0.3-1.0 m depth intervals (for all three reservoirs) and (2) as spatially-explicit shapefiles (BVR and FCR) and triangular irregular networks (TIN) files (FCR and CCR). Watershed areas are included as shapefiles for each reservoir.

additionalInfo.para: The WVWA oversaw and supported bathymetry collection in its three reservoirs. PAG led ADCP measurements and analysis in FCR. KAB led ADCP measurements and analysis in BVR and CCR with help from JCL, CCC, and DWH. CCC and ASL coordinated data documentation and publication. Watershed delineations were led by DWH (CCR) and WMW (FCR + BVR).

The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Beaverdam Reservoir is located in Vinton, Virginia, USA
Falling Creek Reservoir is located in Vinton, Virginia, USA
Carvins Cove Reservoir is located in Roanoke, Virginia, USA

description.para: Bathymetric data for Falling Creek Reservoir, Beaverdam Reservoir (Vinton, VA, USA), and Carvins Cove Reservoir (Roanoke, VA, USA) were estimated following standard methods (e.g., Wahl and Vermeyen 1998). All three reservoirs are owned and operated as either primary (FCR and CCR) or secondary (BVR) drinking water supplies by the Western Virginia Water Authority (WVWA). The data were collected using an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP; RD Instruments, San Diego, CA, USA) operated from a moving boat when both reservoirs were at full pond: ~9.3 m for Falling Creek Reservoir, ~13.5 m for Beaverdam Reservoir, and ~23 m for Carvins Cove Reservoir. Global positioning system (GPS) data were collected simultaneously with the ADCP data collection over multiple transects across both waterbodies. Data from Falling Creek Reservoir and Carvins Cove Reservoir were collected in summer/fall 2012 and data from Beaverdam Reservoir were collected in July 2014. The ADCP and GPS data were processed using WinRiver II software (RD Instruments). To determine hypsometric contours, summary statistics were generated using the Surface Volume (3D Analyst) tool in the 3D Analyst Toolbox in ArcGIS (Esri, Redlands, CA, USA). The data are presented as hypsometric relationships of surface area and volume for 0.3-1.0 m depth intervals in the two reservoirs, as well as in spatially-explicit shapefiles and triangular irregular networks (TIN) files. FCR and BVR spatial bathymetry files use the D North American 1983 coordinate system. CCR spatial bathymetry files use the WGS 1984 UTM Zone 17N coordinate system.

Watershed delineation for CCR was conducted using the StreamStats basin delineation tool provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS; https://streamstats.usgs.gov/ss/). Watershed delineation for FCR and BVR was conducted within ArcGIS Pro using the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer 15 second global digital elevation mode (NASA ASTER GDEM) and the HydroSHEDS stream network layer (Lehner et al. 2008) following the method outlined in Merwade (2012). FCR and BVR watershed files use the D North American 1983 coordinate system. CCR watershed files use the WGS 1984 coordinate system.
Lehner B, Verdin K, Jarvis A. 2008. New global hydrography derived from spaceborne elevation data. Eos Trans AGU. 89:93–94.
Merwade V. 2012. Watershed and stream network delineation using ArcHydro tools. Purdue (IN): University of Purdue, School of Civil Engineering, Printed Lecture Note.
U.S. Geological Survey, 2016, The StreamStats program, online at http://streamstats.usgs.gov, accessed on (27 October 2022).
Wahl, T. and T. Vermeyen (1998). Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) Measurements of Velocity Fields on Upper Klamath Lake Approaching the A-Canal Intake. USBR Report.

dataTable.entityDescription: Data table including bathymetric summary statistics for both reservoirs

attribute.attributeDefinition: Three-letter code corresponding to sampled reservoir
Total surface area of the reservoir at this depth
Volume of water between this depth and the next (deeper) depth below it
Total volume of water below this depth
